title: Former EU ambassador says Theresa May's Brexit Plan B is "insane" - but might happen anyway
text:
Former EU ambassador says Theresa May's Brexit Plan B is "insane" - but might happen anyway Sir Ivan Rogers launched a scathing attack on the idea of leaving with no deal in 2019 if Britain does not get the arrangement wants Share Comments By Arj Singh Dan Bloom 15:16, 22 FEB 2017 Updated 15:20, 22 FEB 2017 News Sir Ivan Rogers said a cliff edge would be "insane"... but might happen anyway (Photo: Dominic Lipinski/PA Wire) Theresa May's Brexit Plan B is "insane", her former ambassador to the EU declared today.
Sir Ivan Rogers launched a scathing attack on the idea of jumping off a "cliff edge" with no deal in 2019 if Britain does not get the arrangement wants.
The Prime Minister has declared "no deal is better than a bad deal" in an ultimatum to the other 27 EU nations.
But Sir Ivan, who dramatically quit the civil service last month, told MPs on the Commons Brexit Committee: "If you had an abrupt cliff edge... there are other consequences in other sectors which would make it an insane thing to do."
Read More 11 things we learned about Brexit from bombshell hearing with ex-EU ambassador Sir Ivan Rogers He accepted neither side would have an interest in leaving without a deal, but warned it could happen anyway.
He said: "This is a very legalistic body that we are dealing with.
Theresa May's now had a fair bit of bad PR from her former ambassador to Brussels (Photo: Getty) "They will say you have transformed yourselves overnight from having been a member of this body to a third country outside the body and in the absence of a new legal agreement everything falls away.
"We all know that that's nuts in the real world, because why would you want to stop UK planes flying into European airports.
"We know that this is insanity ... we know that stopping carcasses and consignments and saying 'your slaughterhouses are no longer approved' - we may know that that is a nonsense in the real world.
"Sadly, that does not stop it necessarily happening."
The dramatic statement came in Sir Ivan's second grilling by MPs since he quit his post in Brussels with a blast at "muddled thinking" over Brexit.
In the first he warned talks will be "humongous", could end in a giant divorce bill and be something like a "fist-fight".
Sir Ivan said the issue of money, including a £50bn 'divorce', is likely to get "gory" (Photo: Getty) Sir Ivan also warned that the EU is unlikely to agree specific deals for industries like car manufacturing - and German Chancellor Angela Merkel has repeatedly said "no sectoral interest will be put above the general interest".
"With Merkel - if she's still there - the unity of the 27 will win out and I think she and others will agree that there will be no sectoral deal", he said.
Sir Ivan said the issue of money, including reports of a £50bn 'divorce' settlement, is likely to get "gory".
He said "the key players, the key officials, the key technocrats, the key theologians" think a new relationship may not be agreed until 2022 even if negotiations proceed "unprecedentedly fast".
And before that deal is struck, European countries may want to keep hold of "British dosh" during a transition period to avoid a squeeze on the Brussels budget.
